name: Quantum Physics I
imgAltText: Lines and boxes showing experimental set-up of a Mach-Zehnder interferometer.
description:
This is the first course in the undergraduate Quantum Physics sequence. It introduces the basic features of quantum mechanics. It covers the experimental basis of quantum physics, introduces wave mechanics, Schrödinger's equation in a single dimension, and Schrödinger's equation in three dimensions. The lectures and lecture notes for this course form the basis of Zwiebach’s textbook *Mastering Quantum Mechanics* published by [MIT Press](https://mitpress.mit.edu/books/mastering-quantum-mechanics) in April 2022.

This presentation of 8.04 by Barton Zwiebach (2016) differs somewhat and complements nicely the presentation of [Allan Adams (2013)](/courses/8-04-quantum-physics-i-spring-2013/). Adams covers a larger set of ideas; Zwiebach tends to go deeper into a smaller set of ideas, offering a systematic and detailed treatment. Adams begins with the subtleties of superpostion, while Zwiebach discusses the surprises of interaction-free measurements. While both courses overlap over a sizable amount of standard material, Adams discussed applications to condensed matter physics, while Zwiebach focused on scattering and resonances. The different perspectives of the instructors make the problem sets in the two courses rather different.
descriptionHtml:
This is the first course in the undergraduate Quantum Physics sequence. It introduces the basic features of quantum mechanics. It covers the experimental basis of quantum physics, introduces wave mechanics, Schrödinger’s equation in a single dimension, and Schrödinger’s equation in three dimensions. The lectures and lecture notes for this course form the basis of Zwiebach’s textbook Mastering Quantum Mechanics published by MIT Press in April 2022.

This presentation of 8.04 by Barton Zwiebach (2016) differs somewhat and complements nicely the presentation of Allan Adams (2013). Adams covers a larger set of ideas; Zwiebach tends to go deeper into a smaller set of ideas, offering a systematic and detailed treatment. Adams begins with the subtleties of superpostion, while Zwiebach discusses the surprises of interaction-free measurements. While both courses overlap over a sizable amount of standard material, Adams discussed applications to condensed matter physics, while Zwiebach focused on scattering and resonances. The different perspectives of the instructors make the problem sets in the two courses rather different.

videos.title: Algebraic solution of the harmonic oscillator
Angular momentum operators and their algebra
Associated Legendre functions and spherical harmonics
Center of mass and relative motion wavefunctions
Comments on the spectrum and continuity conditions
Consistency condition. Particle on a circle
Correspondence principle: amplitude as a function of position
Creation and annihilation operators acting on energy eigenstates
de Broglie wavelength in different frames
Degeneracy in the spectrum and features of the solution
Delta function potential I: Solving for the bound state
Effective potential and boundary conditions at r=0
Effects of resonance on phase shifts, wave amplitude and time delay
Energy below the barrier and phase shift
Energy eigenstates for particle on a circle
Energy eigenstates on a generic symmetric potential. Shooting method
Energy levels and diagram for hydrogen
Excited states of the harmonic oscillator
Finite square well. Setting up the problem
Group velocity and stationary phase approximation
Hamiltonian and emerging spin angular momentum
Incident packet and delay for reflection
Is probability conserved? Hermiticity of the Hamiltonian
Linearity and nonlinear theories. Schrödinger's equation
Momentum operator, energy operator, and a differential equation
More on superposition. General state of a photon and spin states
More on the hydrogen atom degeneracies and orbits
Nodes and symmetries of the infinite square well eigenstates
Nondegeneracy of bound states in 1D. Real solutions
Normalizable wavefunctions and the question of time evolution
Phase shift for a potential well
Photons and the loss of determinism
Qualitative insights: Local de Broglie wavelength
Quantum mechanics as a framework. Defining linearity
Resonances in the complex k plane
Scattering in 1D. Incoming and outgoing waves
Scattering states and the step potential
Series solution and quantization of the energy
Simultaneous eigenstates and quantization of angular momentum
The frequency of a matter wave
The general Schrödinger equation. x, p commutator
The nature of superposition. Mach-Zehnder interferometer
The wave for a free particle
Time evolution of a free particle wavepacket
Units of h and Compton wavelength of particles
Wavepackets with energy below the barrier
Waves on the finite square well
Completeness of eigenvectors and measurement postulate
